On Friday night, the Utah Department of Health issued a public health order clarifying the standards for face coverings in schools.

The order stipulates that every individual on school property, or on a school bus, must wear a face mask that covers the nose and mouth without openings that can be seen through, secures under the chin, and fits snugly against the sides of the nose and the face. Face masks must be worn, even when an individual is able to physical distance, except in very limited circumstances.

Face shields may only be worn without a face mask when the ability to see the mouth is essential for communication, including for an individual who is deaf or hard of hearing or while participating in speech therapy.

View the full text of the public health order, the requirements for masks worn on school property and in school buses here: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1avCe0LRtoYoYPy1GGiP2eACjA211Maff/view.

Congratulations to Tooele Junior High Teacher Morgan Rivera for being selected to participate in the National History Day summer professional development program.

Over the course of the series, she and 97 other teachers, explored digitized primary sources from the Library of Congress, engaged in four live webinar programs and discussions with fellow educators from across the country, and developed resources to use with students in her classroom.

National History Day Executive Director Dr. Cathy Gorn said, “At the conclusion of this course, Mrs. Rivera will be able to share with her students key strategies for researching, supporting, and presenting historical arguments backed up by these primary sources. This is a crucial skill in teaching and learning good history, and is especially valuable now when so many students and teachers across the country are engaged in remote learning due to the coronavirus pandemic.”

As one of the selected teachers, Mrs. Rivera received free tuition, graduate credits, and materials for the online program.

#teamtcsd

It's flag day today. Did you know the current flag was designed by a high school student in Ohio named Bob Heft? He was 17 years old.

In the late 1950's, he figured it was likely that Alaska and Hawaii would be added to the Union. So he borrowed his mother’s sewing machine, disassembled his family’s 48-star flag and stitched on 50 stars in a proportional pattern. He turned in his flag for a history class project. He also sent the flag to his congressman, Walter Moeller, who presented it to President Eisenhower after both new states joined the Union. Eisenhower selected Heft’s design, and on July 4, 1960, the president and the high school student stood together as the 50-star flag was raised for the first time. Heft’s teacher promptly changed his grade from a B- to an A.

COVID-19 is a rapidly-evolving situation, and we are providing information out to our patrons as soon as we receive it.
While there are no reports of COVID-19 in our county, we are preparing for the possibility that the virus could make its way to our area.
*We ask that families get onto ASPIRE SIS to make sure their contact information is up to date.
*Also, in the near future, you may see a survey or flyer asking about a family's access in the home to a computer and internet. We ask that you take a few minutes to fill it out, this will help in the event we need to move classrooms online.
*Lastly, if you or your child are sick, please stay home. We understand this is a nation-wide concern and respect the decision if a parent or caregiver decides to keep their children home from school, (you know your situation best).
In the meantime, we will continue following the guidance provided to us appreciate your help and support.

One school gave each student a yellow wrist band to wear on which students wrote what personally gives them hope.

Earlier this month, 12 of our elementary schools received a delivery of about 150 orange rainbow trout eggs from the Utah Division of Wildlife Resources.

As part of the Trout in the Classroom Program sponsored by Utah Trout Unlimited, students will observe and raise the trout in specialized fish tanks in their classrooms. Then in May, students will release surviving trout into one of three local water bodies (Vernon Reservoir, Settlement Canyon Dam and Grantsville Reservoir).

The Tooele Education Foundation purchased additional tanks this year so more students could be involved in the process of caring for and learning about trout. #teamtcsd
